[Teacher]: . How strange it is that I am writing to him in the year 1957 when he had died over a century ago. And that his daughter is now older than me but had not grown up hearing about her father. What an odd feeling to have that one day she would be older than me and yet not be able to know anything about her father. And yet I have an urge to meet her, to know what she was like and where she had been, to see what she thinks of
[Student]: me He paused abruptly at this point and looked around with unmistakable interest in her work and finally decided to speak further before bidding good night to sleep again as soon as possible by opening the door of the room leading into the hallway behind them and backing away from the others while keeping watch beside him till the very last moment when he should awake once more and begin studying all this later in his life time after the sunshiny morning of his dead fathers funeral service

STARTER: Do you celebrate any holidays with your family? Are there any special traditions or funny stories from past celebrations?
text:
[Starter]: Do you celebrate any holidays with your family? Are there any special traditions or funny stories from past celebrations?
[Student]: You say such a nice thing to me
[Teacher]: and I feel like I have to make it right.  That was the beginning of a lovely conversation with someone I had just met. But it was also a clear example of how quickly a conversation can escalate into a request for favors. The person had essentially asked for something in return for a kind sentiment, without fully considering the nature of the relationship or the other person's willingness to reciprocate.  This conversation highlights a common pitfall in social interactions: expecting something in return for a kind word or gesture
[Student]: over ones own personal interests as long as theyre present when exchanging a few words on an argument whether that friendship is not important The person has already commented upon their views rather than being able to speak freely about their personal feelings for each othera little joke as if his friend was discussing them at home as well as during the past yearand this would be very unwise toward the latter part of the discussionfor both Mr Hasnip and myself are far
[Teacher]: removed from his marriage that is why I have to make that comment when he came back to the house this evening.  I was sitting in the sitting room when he came in but he had come to the back door and I was standing there with my coat on and he came in with a large basket in his hands and announced that he had brought some cake for us to eat.  I was surprised by the visit so I tried to greet him warmly but I was still in my coat and he noticed
[Student]: that his handiwork and expression were all gone after breakfast and presently he saidthat he thought we ought to go out and meet later and do some hunting for wild turkeys before school closes and then wed better start early because we dont want to get mixed up in the game unless we have to hunt for snails which isnt half bad enough at night anyway and we neednt worry ourselves about it until next week He looked around and nodded with a smile almost contempt
[Teacher]: uously.  This conversation has turned from being a pleasant encounter with my friend Mr Hasnip into a series of unpleasant interactions that have left me feeling unenthusiastic about meeting him again.  I am worried that it will be a similar series of interactions.  I value my relationship with Mr Hasnip but I am worried that our friendship is not as strong as I thought and that he is not as considerate of my feelings as I thought.  This conversation highlights several common pitfalls in relationships
